comments.commentBody: No matter how you paint it, no matter how you feel about his commitment.  Look at the league now, and look at the league five years ago.  This has been a success.
bestjets, PLEASE!!! The players share has grown from $34 million in 1994 to $128 million in 2009. If that's not equitable what is?!?

@ Bill D: For all your talk of cities as dynamic places, and change being a constant, you leave out the fact that in this instance the most significant change in effect is that which has been put into motion by corporations and rich people who lack consciousness (many landlords included). You should really check your stance, as it misses the most important piece of the puzzle.

@ J. Edgar Groover: To call Manhattan a "dead scene" is a bit misinformed. First, most musicians featured in the above article live in Brooklyn. Second, there are still more venues in Manhattan (most bands playing on a certain level will agree). Third, yes there is a fairly vibrant scene in Brooklyn, and some great venues, but let's not pretend that it's something more than it is just because Pitchfork says so.

This guy looks like the classic textbook case sociopath: highly intelligent and successful, charming (has fooled even his supposedly intelligent wife), likes to take risks (this time he just went too far) and has a complete lack of empathy. Not all sociopaths are violent, but it seems like this person is of the violent kind (very dangerous indeed). I wouldn't want a violent sociopath living next to me, plus the media circus on top of that (who knows, he may even get death threats).

What’s wrong with international press corps camped out in front of your building for the next three months or even more? It is always nice to meet smart people! It is even better to have one’s views published in the leading newspapers around the world. So the press corps is always welcome on our lawn!
But a suspected sex offender is a very different story...

The man, and this man alone, created this mess. He has no right to force others to be inconvenienced. It was a wise move, but a no-brainer, not to "insist" on staying there, as his attorney says he could have. I wouldn't want to find him sunning himself beside, or swimming in, my pool, ogling the young ladies.

The disruption to the neighbors is totally understandable.  Media personnel will be quite aggressive to get their piece of the pie and will become an unnecessary nonsense to anyone. So on that basis ok fine.  But as I read op eds and watch reaction to this media event I can't help but think that what we have so far is on the one hand an accusation and on the other a man with a reputation.

Whatever the reasons stated  for refusing DSK stay in their building the residents come out as snobs  at best . The illusion that money paid for th e privilege of living there entitle them for protection against unwanted publicity. Do they think it will protect them against natural catastrophe too?
Innocent or not, but so much shame and embarrassment, how can a person tolerate it?

First off, they are no longer a Union. Second of all, the players have nothing. They've lost and the only thing to do is concede. The only thing to decide is whether it is going to be sooner or later. Hopefully, for us the fans, its sooner.

NYT editor: You're right. It's been fixed.
My compliments to Mr. Paine for not ending his last sentence with a preposition.
Anyone care to comment on the Giambino's performance last night?

My original authority on Wally Schang was Bill James who put him on his short list of those unjustly denied HOF induction and who identified Schang as one of the very best catchers of his era. According to SABR's Baseball Biography Project, "A switch-hitter who was adept at getting on base, Wally Schang was considered by many of his contemporaries to be the best catcher of his time. Behind the plate, the 5’10”, 180-pounder was one of the most athletic catchers of his day, so agile and alert that he occasionally played third base or in the outfield..."

A fair objection to putting Schang on the list of greatest Yankee catchers might be that he only played for them for 5 years -- but they were the years the Yanks started winning (their first 3 pennants and first WS win). That's why his WAR total looks low -- you're comparing him to career Yankees. For his career Schang's total WAR is 43.8, statistically the same as Posada and Munson. Since obviously I never saw him play, I rate Schang ahead based on the impression formed by my reading, including the James's HOF advocacy, which I don't think applies to Posada.

On the other hand, I rate Howard ahead of Posada based in part, perhaps, on the bias of childhood nostalgia for the Yankees of the '50s and '60s, then factoring in the burden of his pioneer status as the first black man on the Yankees, and finally considering his rather monumental achievements -- stardom, really -- in the early 60s. I don't think WAR tells the whole story, though perhaps it does for Aaron Robinson, I don't know.

I love Posada. I saw him play his first professional season for the Oneonta Yankees when he was 19 and they were just starting to convert him to catcher. There's a long line of fiery, proud, temperamental guys who've gone on to make great managers, and I'm not worried about the recent meltdown.

You've nicely highlighted two of the key problems of current US attempts to improve education en masse. One is the fundamental (and flawed) assumption that good teaching is the only thing needed to produce good education. Teachers, even great ones, can only do so much with the time and resources they have access to. It's not uncommon for a kid to spend more time in front of the TV (or other screen) than in the classroom.

The other, which is not addressed by the programs described in this article, is the punitive nature of the attempts to fix things. Students not up to snuff in standardized exams? Threaten the teachers and schools with loss of resources and potential firing. That'll learn them! Parents not supervising homework, feeding their kids nutritious meals and volunteering at the school? Berate them, fine them, and threaten to jail them. That's make them parent better!

Both approaches ignore the fundamental issue that the best way to predict students' performance in multiple areas is to look at where they live, and the income and education levels of their parents. You're not going to solve that by using punitive measures to get teachers to teach harder, and parents to parent harder.

I was talking to a colleague who had lived in the US (Los Angeles area) when his kids were small. I asked him about the education system, and he said it was actually fairly easy to get your kids a good education in the US. The secret was to buy a cheap house in an expensive neighbourhood. That says a lot about the system as a whole.

@Kate (#23),
I was making a generalization to demonstrate a point - that you cannot separate schools based on performance without taking the economic circumstances into consideration. It stands to reason that GENERALLY parents with higher incomes have more time to commit to volunteering at schools (SAHMs contributing the most time) and obsessing over their children's homework, leading to better performance. And conversely, school districts with less resources are USUALLY attended by children whose parents must work longer hours, sometimes multiple shifts, or perhaps just can't afford childcare for younger siblings while they attend school functions. It certainly doesn't mean these parents don't care about their children's education, and I'm sure many attend PTA meetings when they are able. It doesn't change the fact that their children have to be responsible for themselves to a greater extent, and punishing these already time and cash-strapped parents is only going to cause problems, not solve them.

The IMF and the World Bank are both organizations that overflow in number of nut cases such as DSK and what is worse harassment (i..e. based on nationality and gender) and corruption are massive ..... and when I state massive I mean massive ! Never ever forget about the old adage : "Where there are takers there are givers"

If proven guilty, what a betrayal....
And if not, majority will agree, the damage is done.

And as the authors said, the lesson to be learned is that life does catch up with you sooner or later. And maybe certain things which can be (rightfully or perhaps wrongfully) ignored in our daily lives as just 'libertine' behaviour, can turn out to have diametrically opposite outcomes in some other space, another time....

All in all, how difficult such probing media focus for the family.
According to Ralph W Emerson,"Bad behavior, the laws cannot reach'.... or can it not?

The narrative of what transpired during the fifteen minutes the chambermaid claims she was assaulted by DSK- does not make any sense. It just does not add up.  Hence, I agree with Madame Sinclair, I believe her husband is innocent and will be vindicated.

Strange, I was not aware that he was Jewish until this article. His name of course should be a dead givaway- but it it not his Jewishness that is the crux or even relevant unless his wife has something to prove in France.

This affair has struck a chord with so many women on so many intricate levels. Many of us have learned not to make waves even under the crudist of assaults. In my era women dared not consider themselvelves
intellectually equal to men, be a president- it was not possible.

I feel a sisterhood with those young female servants who were raped and dismissed when they got pregnant as morally corrupt by Lords of the Manor in centuries past.

It is fortunate that biology still plays an important part in women's desire for men, as their past behaviour certainly has not.
These people are, well, ya know, Socialists, right?  What?  Are we to expect something different in the way they behave?

Unfortunate, in the circumstances, that his biographer describes his seduction of her as a subjugation.

The way to prepare for this? There is one: don't be an enabler by turning a blind eye to his behaviours, let alone justifying, rationalising and praising them to anyone who will listen.

The evidence against him must be well-nigh incontrovertible for the authorities to have acted as they did.

I have not one scrap of sympathy for him or his enabling, 'subjugated' wife.

Strange, how someone with a beautiful, successful, intelligent, rich wife goes for the chambermaid . . . He's probably bored with the chateaus and Porsches, flying first-class is a drag and the vintage Bordeaux is tasting a little flat . . .

He might be lucky to get prison.
This woman was probably attracted to the influence and fame of her husband, so the loss of it will be a big shock to her. Off the subject, but just what is an "extraordinary apartment" ?

Ms. Sinclair could be taken more seriously if at least she had a word of compassion for the victims of his husband that have been silenced for years. Now even the leaders of the Socialist Party start to acknowledge that a group of men close to DSK, known as "the firemen" (les pompiers), were dedicated to silence those victims by persuasion or intimidation. Someday she will discover that there are more important values in life than power, fame, and money.

And by the way, Picasso was also a brutal abuser or women.

Anne Sinclair appears to be a formidable woman.  M. Strauss-Kahn is fortunate to have her at his side.  I hope that Ms. Sinclair's confidence in her husband is rewarded.  As well, I hope that Ms. Sinclair has family and friends who will help her navigate this ordeal.  I understand that Ms. Sinclair has very substantial financial resources, but she will need support from others, as well. Note that my admiration for Ms. Sinclair does not mean that I believe that her husband is innocent.  In that matter, I will await a verdict from the courts.
